AUSTRALIA

Bank of Queensland (BOQ AT) - Co. H1 cash earnings after tax fell 8% Y/Y to AUD 167mln vs. Exp. AUD 168mln, sees H2 earnings unlikely to improve from H1. (Newswires)

Challenger Financial Services (CGF AT) - Co. enters agreement to sell its 31 Queen Street tower in Melbourne for AUD 200mln. (Newswires)

Origin Energy (ORG AT) - New South Wales government could announce plans to sell its 49.6% stake in Ausgrid and Endeavor Energy. (AFR)

Qantas (QAN AT) - Co. announces Qantas International CEO Webster has resigned. (Newswires)

Stockland (SGP AT) - Co. is looking at indicative bids for its retirement living portfolio. (Newswires)

Whitehaven Coal (WHC AT) - Co. Q3 managed ROM coal production 4.9k tons vs. Prev. 5.9k tons Y/Y. (Newswires)

Other News - Australian PM Morrison called for the election to be held on May 18th. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

ABC-MART (2670 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 30.3bln vs. Prev. JPY 29.7bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Aeon (8267 JT) - Co. FY net fell 3.6% Y/Y to JPY 23.6bln. (Newswires) - Aeon Hokkaido (7512 JT) and Maxvalu Hokkaido (7465 JT) reach merger agreement.

FamilyMart Uny Holdings (8028 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 45.4bln vs. Prev. JPY 33.7bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Leopalace21 (8848 JT) - Co. confirms that around 3.8k additional buildings have problems. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Co. is reportedly to expand capacity of its Pretoria plant for the Navara pick up with a USD 213mln investment. (Newswires)

OJI Holdings (3861 JT) - Co. plans to enter pharmaceuticals industry. (Newswires)

Sharp (6753 JT) - Co. announces foldable OLED screens for smartphones and cars. (Nikkei)

Telecoms - SoftBank (9984 JT) is to invest JPY 206bln into 5G, while NTT DoCoMo (9437 JT) is to invest JPY 795bln and KDDI (9433 JT) is to invest JPY 466bln. (Newswires)

Other News -Japan is to reportedly reject any auto quotas or FX provisions in talks with the US. (Nikkei)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Asiana Airlines (020560 KS) - Kumho Asiana said it needs an additional KRW 500bln of financial help from its creditors and vowed to offload its flagship Asiana Airlines if it fails to meet creditors' demands in 3 years. (Yonhap)

SK Innovation (096770 KS) - Co. is near to an agreement to build a 2nd EV battery factory. (Newswires)

Other News - North Korea Leader Kim said the country needs to deliver a serious blow to those imposing sanctions, according to reports citing North Korean state media. (Yonhap) - North Korea Leader Kim may conduct talks with Russian President Putin in Russia soon. (Asahi)

content:
FOMC MINUTES

FOMC Minutes stated that a majority of policy makers expected rates to remain steady this year and that the Fed's patient approach on rates is needed given uncertainties including global and financial developments. The Minutes also noted that some policymakers thought a modest hike could be warranted later this year and several policymakers said their view could change on the Fed's next move whether that should be a hike or a cut. (Newswires)

Furthermore, several policymakers preferred to stabilise reserves by resuming treasury purchases soon after balance sheet runoff and some suggested to discuss cost benefits of tools to reduce reserves demand and support interest rate control. Policymakers also saw continued US economic growth, strong labour market and inflation near the Fed's objective as the most likely outcome in the next few years, while several expressed concern over the flat yield curve, but highlighted that the historical relationship is less reliable. 

ASIA-PAC

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said they had a very productive meeting with Chinese officials, while he added that a call is scheduled for tomorrow morning and there are still important issues to address. Mnuchin also noted that an enforcement mechanism has been agreed and that the sides will set up enforcement offices. (Newswires/FT)

Australian PM Morris is said to be on the way to government house and is expected to call an election which must be held by 18th May 2019 for half-Senate and 2nd November 2019 for the House of Representatives. (Newswires) 

UK

EU officials said UK PM May's speech at the leaders' summit was "more solid than usual, though not many specifics" and that there is a sense that May is "open to a longer extension as long as it can be terminated early". Furthermore, most EU27 states reportedly support a long extension to the Brexit and the EU was said to be angling towards a 9-12month Brexit extension. However, French President Macron was said to be pushing for a Brexit extension to the end of June and a French Presidency official also noted their view is that current Brexit documents being drafted do not include serious guarantees which does not allow for a long extension. (Newswires)

UK government sources stated that UK PM May will make a statement on the results of her meeting with EU leaders at midday tomorrow and that MPs are unlikely to be asked to attend House of Commons next week although this has not been confirmed. Elsewhere, it was also reported that UK PM May will seek to stay on as PM if Brexit deal is not passed by end-June (Newswires/Guardian)

  • UK GDP Estimate (Feb) M/M 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.0% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires)
  • UK GDP Estimate (Feb) Y/Y 2.0% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.4%)
  • UK Industrial Output (Feb) Y/Y 0.1% vs. Exp. -0.9% (Prev. -0.9%, Rev. -0.3%)
  • UK Manufacturing Output (Feb) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. -0.7% (Prev. -1.1%, Rev. -0.7%)
  • UK Goods Trade Balance (GBP)(Feb) -14.112B vs. Exp. -12.7B (Prev. -13.08B, Rev. -14.623B)

 

EU

  • ECB Lending Rate 0.25% vs. Exp. 0.25% (Prev. 0.25%). (Newswires)
  • ECB Refinancing Rate (Apr) 0.00% vs. Exp. 0.00% (Prev. 0.00%)
  • ECB Deposit Rate (Apr) -0.40% vs. Exp. -0.40% (Prev. -0.40%)

 

ECB statement repeated it expects rates to be kept at present levels through the end of 2019 and for as long as necessary to ensure convergence of inflation towards the target, while it also repeated guidance on reinvestments in which it will reinvest for an extended time even after the first rate hike. 

ECB President Draghi said Governing Council members are acknowledging weakening of the economy and that incoming data is weak, reflecting external demand and country specific factors with the impact of these factors longer lasting. Draghi added Euro area growth risks are tilted to the downside and that an ample degree of monetary accommodation is still required, while he also commented that the central bank is in the process of analysing the impacts of negative rates on bank profits.

ECB's Draghi also commented that TLTRO details will be announced in forthcoming meetings and will take into account assessment of bank-based transmission, while they will consider whether preservation of negative rates requires mitigation. However, Draghi also commented that it is too early to discuss terms of the TLTRO or to decide about tiering which needs further analysis, while they also did not discuss rate guidance and the main goal of the meeting was to reassert readiness to act if needed.

EU's Dombrovskis said EU is discussing trade issues with US and is hopeful the sides avoid an escalation of trade tensions, while Dombrovskis also noted they have seen some slowdown in the bloc's economies and that the Italian slowdown is partly due to government decisions. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 7.029M vs. Exp. 2.294M (Prev. 7.238M). (Newswires)

OPEC monthly report stated that OPEC crude production fell 534k bpd in March to average 30.02mln bpd, according to secondary sources. Furthermore, compliance of members bound by supply cut deal was reported at 155% (exp. 135%), while crude oil output decreased mostly in Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Iran, and Iraq. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea Leader Kim says the country needs to deliver a serious blow to those imposing sanctions, according to Yonhap citing state media. (Yonhap) 

US

US President Trump said the US people want a Fed chair who does not raise rates. (Newswires)

Canada government are reportedly preparing to announce retaliatory tariffs against the US. (The Star)

  • US CPI (Mar) M/M 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.2%). (Newswires)
  • US CPI (Mar) Y/Y 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.5%)
  • US Core CPI (Mar) Y/Y 2.0% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 2.1%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Boeing (BA) was a dragger on indices again today after it reported a big fall in 737 MAX orders in March as well as receiving a price target lowering at JPMorgan. Levi Strauss (LEVI) surged on its debut public earnings release, where it showed strong advances in top and bottom line growth. Conagra Brands (CAG) outperformed following an investor presentation where it provided optimistic guidance. Delta Air Lines (DAL) opened higher on strong earnings and improved revenue guidance. AmerisourceBergen (ABC) nosedived after Evercore downgraded the drug distributor on profit concerns. Disney (DIS) received a tailwind from BMO Capital upgrading and raising the price target for the stock. Chipmakers (AMD, XLNX, INTC) caught a bid amidst a bullish research note on the sector from Cowen, who sees the sector recovering in H2 2019. Automakers, particularly Tesla (TSLA) and General Motors (GM), gained upward momentum following US lawmakers suggesting a bill for increased tax credits for electric vehicles. Kroger (KR) benefitted from a positive mention at Credit Suisse, who see robust profit ahead. Nordstrom (JWN) traded higher after KeyBanc upgraded the apparel retailer. Jet Blue Airways (JBLU) took off on improved March traffic and the teasing of a new transatlantic route. Under Armour (UAA) opened in the green with thanks to an upgrade at Citi. SPX +0.4% at 2889, NDX +0.6% at 7611, DJI 0.0% at 26160.

Decent IP data out of Europe helped the TPLEX find sellers in the premarket, though buyers emerged ahead of the US cash equity open. A mixed CPI report (headline up, core down) saw a chunky block in the TY June contract. After the data, ECB President Draghi’s reiteration of downside risks saw the T-note move in sympathy with the Bund, sending Treasuries to 1-week highs. There was a breather after the European cash close, where book squaring was reported ahead of the 10-year auction. The auction itself was fairly good, stopping through the screens by 1bps, while indirect bidder participation provided some encouragement. The Fed’s latest meeting minutes stuck to the script, though perhaps weren’t as dovish as some might have predicted after the outcome of the March policy meeting. That left major curve spreads mixed at settlement. US T-note futures (M9) settled 5 ticks higher at 123-25+.

subject: US MARKET WRAP 10 April 2019: Minutes suggest Fed did not discuss rate cuts at March meeting
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar down, Treasuries up, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Fed mins slightly more hawkish than expected; US headline CPI beats, core dips; ECB remains cautious, and vague on TLTRO3 details; New BCB Governor Neto on the outlook; More bearish OPEC monthly report;

* AHEAD: Chinese, German & French CPI; US Initial Jobless Claims & PPI; New Zealand Manufacturing PMI; IEA Monthly Report; ECB's de Galhua; Fed's Clarida, Bullard, Williams, Kashkari & Bowman; Supply from US & Italy

* FOMC: There was nothing in the Fed meeting minutes to suggest that the central bank was on the cusp of cutting rates. In fact, the majority of officials see rates steady this year, while the patient approach was needed amid uncertainties that include the global economy, trade and Brexit (policymakers wanted to review this ‘patient’ stance regularly). Some even thought that modest rate rises might be warranted later in the year, while several said they could shift their view on whether the next appropriate move should be a rate hike or cut (note: in the Fed’s March forecasts, it took rate hikes off the table for the rest of the year). There was not much on the balance sheet for traders to get their teeth into. On the economic outlook, the Fed saw continued US economic growth (Q1 weakness likely transitory), strong labour market and inflation near target as the most likely outcome in the next few years. There were some concerns expressed on the yield curve, but policymakers noted that the historical relationship with growth is less reliable. Net/net, the minutes reiterate the view that the Fed is firmly on hold, and that if data comes in in line with expectations, the next move could be up. This may have disappointed the doves, who were looking to the meeting minutes for evidence that the Fed was/may consider cutting rates in the months ahead, as US President Donald Trump and his Fed Board nominee Stephen Moore have called for. The probability of a rate cut was relatively unchanged in wake of the minutes, according to money markets, which imply a 55% chance of a rate cut; some have argued that there is little in the economic landscape that makes a compelling case for rate cuts at present, and as such the pricing could be a reflection of the market’s view that we are at/near the end of the cycle; it could also be a function of threats to the Fed’s independence from the Trump administration, which prefers lower rates. Either way, there is not much in the minutes that significantly shifts the Fed’s narrative, and as such, it will be in wait and see mode in the weeks/potentially months ahead.

* US CPI: Headline CPI rose 0.4% M/M, beating the forecast 0.3%, helping to boost the Y/Y measure by 0.1ppts to 1.9% in March. The Core measure fell 0.1% M/M vs +0.2% expected, dragging the Y/Y measure down 0.1ppts to 2.0%. The core measure was held back by a fall in apparel prices, and excluding this item, the core measure rose by 0.2% M/M. Pantheon Macroeconomics says the fall might have been a result of a change in the data collection methodology, and the consultancy said it may be a one-off. "Elsewhere, the components responsible for most of the modest 0.1% core increase in February - medical services, recreation, and medical commodities - rebounded in March, at least in part, but used auto prices fell for the second straight month, by 0.4%," Pantheon writes, "The CPI used auto measure remains much stronger than implied by auction price data, so we expect further declines." But in contrast, the consultancy says that rents are rising strongly, well above trend and the biggest increase since February 2007. "This might just be noise, and we note that owners' equivalent rents rose less quickly, up 0.32%," but the consultancy is reluctant to dismiss the numbers since "the dip in the vacancy rate to a 34-year low, coupled with faster wage growth, is consistent with the idea that rental inflation will rise," and "the three-month annualized rate of increase of combined primary rents and OER reached 3.9% in March, the fastest increase on this basis since June 2016. It could easily mean-revert quickly to the prior trend, 3.3%, but rents account for 41% of the core CPI so the data need to be watched closely."

* TRADE: Appearing on CNBC, US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said he had a very productive meeting with Chinese officials and has a further call scheduled for tomorrow morning. He said that although there were still important issues to be addressed, an enforcement mechanism, which had previously been a sticking point, had been agreed upon. He gave no detail regarding a timeline for tariff removal but did go on to say that US President Trump is ready and willing to meet with China President Xi and reiterated that the Trump administration is working full-time on the deal.

* ECB REVIEW: As was touted ahead of the release, this week’s ECB policy announcement provided little in the way of fireworks with all three key rates maintained and no changes to the monetary policy statement. As such, a bulk of the focus fell upon the follow-up press conference with President Draghi. In his assessment of the Eurozone economy, Draghi noted that incoming data is weak, reflecting external demand and country specific factors, adding that the impact of these factors is longer lasting. Ultimately, the ECB Chief maintained his assessment that Euro area growth risks are tilted to the downside. On the inflation front, the Governing Council noted that underlying inflation is muted with headline inflation likely to decline over the coming months but expected to increase over the medium-term. During the Q&A segment of the press conference, Draghi noted that he wishes to dispel the notion that the ECB will tolerate low inflation and that policymakers are committed to returning inflation towards 2% without delay and ultimately, the 2% goal is not a ceiling. Naturally, journalists looked to extract more details from the President on TLTRO3, however, Draghi batted away such efforts by stating that details will be announced in forthcoming meetings. The ECB Chief also took a similar approach to the prospect of topic of prospective tiered rates at the Bank, however, did acknowledge that policymakers will need to consider whether or not the preservation of negative interest rates requires mitigation. From a rate guidance perspective, despite the account of the March meeting stating that some policymakers wanted to push guidance out further into 2020 (as opposed to end of 2019), Draghi suggested that such a move was not discussed at this meeting and instead the purpose of the meeting was to reassert the Bank’s readiness to act if needed with the President noting that “we are ready to use all instruments”. Overall, ING concludes “The ECB first wants to spend more time in the study room before announcing details of the new TLTROs or even presenting measures to bring relief to the banks”.

* BREXIT: There was nothing fresh on the Brexit front; May delivered a pitch to EU leaders which was reportedly more solid than usual, though there weren’t many specifics, and EU officials after said there was a sense that May might be open to a longer Brexit extension, as long as it can be ended early. The draft conclusions of the EU27 statement will likely include language giving the EU permission to have more meetings without the UK during the extension process, and are to say that the UK should refrain from any measure which could jeopardise EU objectives. Behind the scenes, there were reports that France and Germany were split about the length of the Article 50 extensions, with the French continuing to want a shorter extension, though the Germans seemed more amenable – as they have in recent weeks – to ensuring the process is smooth, without issues, and more supportive of longer extensions (a 9-month to 12-month extension is reportedly being mulled, while a French official was quoted as saying that the current Brexit documents do not include serious guarantees, which would not allow for a long extension in France’s view) There was some chatter that the May press conference has been brought forward slightly, which may indicate that ‘things are going to plan’ one reporter said.

* BCB: New governor Campos Neto was on the wires, noting that the international outlook remains challenging, and the risk profile is shifting, while risks were still tilted towards lower growth, and that while the recovery is gradual, it is not quite as monetary authorities had expected. Campos Neto made pro-business noises, saying he was working to reduce the cost of financial transactions and improving competitions. He also said he wants to simplify the foreign exchange market, with the aim of having a fully convertible currency, arguing that if reforms are done correctly, the BRL might strengthen as a result; he said there was no target for the FX rate. He also said that the FX reserves policy has been a very good insurance policy, at a minimum cost. On the central bank's objectives, Campos Neto said the mission is to achieve the inflation target, not growth, adding that the BCB would not take risks with keeping inflation under control. The central bank chief also noted that challenges faced by fiscal policy: pension reforms, public sector salaries, and interest on debt. The BCB's base case is tat the reforms will be approved, and will analyse the impact it has on FX reserve policy.

* OPEC MONTHLY REPORT: OPEC crude production fell 534k bpd in March to average 30.02mln bpd. Compliance of members bound by supply cut deal reported at 155% (exp. 135%). Crude oil output decreased mostly in Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Iran, and Iraq, while production increased in Libya, Congo and Nigeria. Venezuela tells OPEC production fell by 472k BPD to 960k BPD, a new long-term low, amid US sanctions and blackouts. Total world oil demand growth in 2018 is estimated at 1.41mln bpd, down 20k bpd from last month’s estimate due to weaker Q4 2018 oil demand data from OECD Asia-Pac. For 2019, oil demand growth is forecast at around 1.21mln bpd vs last month’s 1.24mln bpd forecast due to slower-than-expected economic activity, the EIA also cut its 2019 world oil demand growth. Non-OPEC oil supply growth in 2018 was revised up by 160k bpd from the previous month’s report. Non-OPEC oil supply growth in 2019 was revised lower by 60k bpd to average 2.18mln BPD.

* WTI FUTURES (K9) SETTLE USD AT USD; BRENT (M9) SETTLES USD AT USD. The oil complex marched forward on Wednesday to re-test YTD highs seen earlier in the week. The US energy inventory data is bound to have muddied the waters for participants, where crude stocks built by a hefty 7mln bbls, above the expected 2.3mln build and superseding the API reported 4.1mln build; however, gasoline stocks moved in the opposite direction, drawing by 7.7mln bbls, greater than the expected 2.3mln draw; the Cushing, Oklahoma delivery hub also reported stocks drawing by 1.1mln bbls. Price movements were choppy after the release. It's worth keeping in mind that the energy complex is underpinned by supply-side woes emanating from conflicts in Libya, markets are pricing in a potential disruption. El-Sharara oil field is currently producing under capacity (290k vs. full capacity of 300-315k), whilst an explosion occurred near a pipeline that connect El-Feel oilfield (340k) to Zawiya port (scheduled to load 6mln barrels in April). Recent ICE & CME data continues to show long positions expanding in WTI and Brent, with analysts at PVM noting, “a word of caution is in order. The current overhang of speculative length in both crude markers could spark a downward spiral in oil prices. That is if the uncertainty surrounding the global economic outlook and OPEC+ production strategy in the second half of the year intensifies. You’ve been warned.” Elsewhere, there were signs that the WTI/Brent arb is weighing on US exports, which declined to 2.35mln BPD in the week (vs 2.7mln last week).

* SPX +0.4% at 2889, NDX +0.6% at 7611, DJI 0,0% at 26160. SECTORS: Communications +1.2%, Cons Discretionary +0.5%, Cons Staples +0.3%, Energy +0.4%, Financials +0.3%, Healthcare +0.1%, Industrials 0.0%, Materials 0.0%, Tech +0.7%, Telecoms +0.3%, Utilities -0.4%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) was a dragger on indices again today after it reported a big fall in 737 MAX orders in March as well as receiving a price target lowering at JPMorgan. Levi Strauss (LEVI) surged on its debut public earnings release, where it showed strong advances in top and bottom line growth. Conagra Brands (CAG) outperformed following an investor presentation where it provided optimistic guidance. Delta Air Lines (DAL) opened higher on strong earnings and improved revenue guidance. AmerisourceBergen (ABC) nosedived after Evercore downgraded the drug distributor on profit concerns. Disney (DIS) received a tailwind from BMO Capital upgrading and raising the price target for the stock. Chipmakers (AMD, XLNX, INTC) caught a bid amidst a bullish research note on the sector from Cowen, who sees the sector recovering in H2 2019. Automakers, particularly Tesla (TSLA) and General Motors (GM), gained upward momentum following US lawmakers suggesting a bill for increased tax credits for electric vehicles. Kroger (KR) benefitted from a positive mention at Credit Suisse, who see robust profit ahead. Nordstrom (JWN) traded higher after KeyBanc upgraded the apparel retailer. Jet Blue Airways (JBLU) took off on improved March traffic and the teasing of a new transatlantic route. Under Armour (UAA) opened in the green with thanks to an upgrade at Citi.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLE 5 TICKS HIGHER AT 123-25+. Decent IP data out of Europe helped the TPLEX find sellers in the premarket, though buyers emerged ahead of the US cash equity open. A mixed CPI report (headline up, core down) saw a chunky block in the TY June contract. After the data, ECB President Draghi’s reiteration of downside risks saw the T-note move in sympathy with the Bund, sending Treasuries to 1-week highs. There was a breather after the European cash close, where book squaring was reported ahead of the 10-year auction. The auction itself was fairly good, stopping through the screens by 1bps, while indirect bidder participation provided some encouragement. The Fed’s latest meeting minutes stuck to the script, though perhaps weren’t as dovish as some might have predicted after the outcome of the March policy meeting. That left major curve spreads mixed at settlement.

* 30-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: The February auction saw the lowest yield at a 30s auction since July 2018, though cover slipped versus the previous month. Analysts at SocGen note that current 30s are trading fair in asset swap from a relative value perspective, but the 5s30s has flattened form multi-month highs at the end of March. The bank also says that the WI is trading beneath all of the 30-year auction stop-out rates since January 2018, which could be a negative factor leading to poor takedown. However, it does say that the current 30 trades rich in repo, which could offset negative factors, and accordingly, it holds a slight negative bias going into the auction.

* FX WRAP: As we head into APAC trade, there is a feeling of disappointment that FX moves were so limited on what had been dubbed “Super Wednesday”. The EUR trades up 0.1%, rebounding from losses seen through the ECB press conference as Draghi reiterated downside risks (there wasn’t much new). The DXY is down around 0.1% after the Fed continued to signal a ‘wait and see’ approach. The AUD was higher on short-covering, with the RBA’s Debelle overnight not signalling any easing bias from the central bank. GBP bias was to the upside amid a slightly stronger EUR and weaker GBP; sterling is seen as a buy on dips, as traders price out the no deal downside, and with an extension likely to be be signed-off on by the end of this week, no deal Brexit concerns will be booted into the long grass for another day. EMFX was up, particularly the BRL which gained on the central bank governor making pro business noises, while the economy minister reiterated his drive for pension reform. The ZAR was an outperformer, with wires attributing the strength to an easing of US/China tensions.

Net/net, the minutes reiterate the view that the Fed is firmly on hold, and that if data comes in in line with expectations, the next move could be up. This may have disappointed the doves, who were looking to the meeting minutes for evidence that the Fed was/may consider cutting rates in the months ahead, as US President Donald Trump and his Fed Board nominee Stephen Moore have called for. The probability of a rate cut was relatively unchanged in wake of the minutes, according to money markets, which imply a 55% chance of a rate cut; some have argued that there is little in the economic landscape that makes a compelling case for rate cuts at present, and as such the pricing could be a reflection of the market’s view that we are at/near the end of the cycle; it could also be a function of threats to the Fed’s independence from the Trump administration, which prefers lower rates. Either way, there is not much in the minutes that significantly shifts the Fed’s narrative, and as such, it will be in wait and see mode in the weeks/potentially months ahead.

* US CPI: Headline CPI rose 0.4% M/M, beating the forecast 0.3%, helping to boost the Y/Y measure by 0.1ppts to 1.9% in March. The Core measure fell 0.1% M/M vs +0.2% expected, dragging the Y/Y measure down 0.1ppts to 2.0%. The core measure was held back by a fall in apparel prices, and excluding this item, the core measure rose by 0.2% M/M. Pantheon Macroeconomics says the fall might have been a result of a change in the data collection methodology, and the consultancy said it may be a one-off. "Elsewhere, the components responsible for most of the modest 0.1% core increase in February - medical services, recreation, and medical commodities - rebounded in March, at least in part, but used auto prices fell for the second straight month, by 0.4%," Pantheon writes, "The CPI used auto measure remains much stronger than implied by auction price data, so we expect further declines." But in contrast, the consultancy says that rents are rising strongly, well above trend and the biggest increase since February 2007. "This might just be noise, and we note that owners' equivalent rents rose less quickly, up 0.32%," but the consultancy is reluctant to dismiss the numbers since "the dip in the vacancy rate to a 34-year low, coupled with faster wage growth, is consistent with the idea that rental inflation will rise," and "the three-month annualized rate of increase of combined primary rents and OER reached 3.9% in March, the fastest increase on this basis since June 2016. It could easily mean-revert quickly to the prior trend, 3.3%, but rents account for 41% of the core CPI so the data need to be watched closely."

* TRADE: Appearing on CNBC, US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said he had a very productive meeting with Chinese officials and has a further call scheduled for tomorrow morning. He said that although there were still important issues to be addressed, an enforcement mechanism, which had previously been a sticking point, had been agreed upon. He gave no detail regarding a timeline for tariff removal but did go on to say that US President Trump is ready and willing to meet with China President Xi and reiterated that the Trump administration is working full-time on the deal.

* ECB REVIEW: As was touted ahead of the release, this week’s ECB policy announcement provided little in the way of fireworks with all three key rates maintained and no changes to the monetary policy statement. As such, a bulk of the focus fell upon the follow-up press conference with President Draghi. In his assessment of the Eurozone economy, Draghi noted that incoming data is weak, reflecting external demand and country specific factors, adding that the impact of these factors is longer lasting. Ultimately, the ECB Chief maintained his assessment that Euro area growth risks are tilted to the downside. On the inflation front, the Governing Council noted that underlying inflation is muted with headline inflation likely to decline over the coming months but expected to increase over the medium-term. During the Q&A segment of the press conference, Draghi noted that he wishes to dispel the notion that the ECB will tolerate low inflation and that policymakers are committed to returning inflation towards 2% without delay and ultimately, the 2% goal is not a ceiling. Naturally, journalists looked to extract more details from the President on TLTRO3, however, Draghi batted away such efforts by stating that details will be announced in forthcoming meetings. The ECB Chief also took a similar approach to the prospect of topic of prospective tiered rates at the Bank, however, did acknowledge that policymakers will need to consider whether or not the preservation of negative interest rates requires mitigation. From a rate guidance perspective, despite the account of the March meeting stating that some policymakers wanted to push guidance out further into 2020 (as opposed to end of 2019), Draghi suggested that such a move was not discussed at this meeting and instead the purpose of the meeting was to reassert the Bank’s readiness to act if needed with the President noting that “we are ready to use all instruments”. Overall, ING concludes “The ECB first wants to spend more time in the study room before announcing details of the new TLTROs or even presenting measures to bring relief to the banks”.

* BREXIT: There was nothing fresh on the Brexit front; May delivered a pitch to EU leaders which was reportedly more solid than usual, though there weren’t many specifics, and EU officials after said there was a sense that May might be open to a longer Brexit extension, as long as it can be ended early. The draft conclusions of the EU27 statement will likely include language giving the EU permission to have more meetings without the UK during the extension process, and are to say that the UK should refrain from any measure which could jeopardise EU objectives. Behind the scenes, there were reports that France and Germany were split about the length of the Article 50 extensions, with the French continuing to want a shorter extension, though the Germans seemed more amenable – as they have in recent weeks – to ensuring the process is smooth, without issues, and more supportive of longer extensions (a 9-month to 12-month extension is reportedly being mulled, while a French official was quoted as saying that the current Brexit documents do not include serious guarantees, which would not allow for a long extension in France’s view) There was some chatter that the May press conference has been brought forward slightly, which may indicate that ‘things are going to plan’ one reporter said.

* BCB: New governor Campos Neto was on the wires, noting that the international outlook remains challenging, and the risk profile is shifting, while risks were still tilted towards lower growth, and that while the recovery is gradual, it is not quite as monetary authorities had expected. Campos Neto made pro-business noises, saying he was working to reduce the cost of financial transactions and improving competitions. He also said he wants to simplify the foreign exchange market, with the aim of having a fully convertible currency, arguing that if reforms are done correctly, the BRL might strengthen as a result; he said there was no target for the FX rate. He also said that the FX reserves policy has been a very good insurance policy, at a minimum cost. On the central bank's objectives, Campos Neto said the mission is to achieve the inflation target, not growth, adding that the BCB would not take risks with keeping inflation under control. The central bank chief also noted that challenges faced by fiscal policy: pension reforms, public sector salaries, and interest on debt. The BCB's base case is tat the reforms will be approved, and will analyse the impact it has on FX reserve policy.

* OPEC MONTHLY REPORT: OPEC crude production fell 534k bpd in March to average 30.02mln bpd. Compliance of members bound by supply cut deal reported at 155% (exp. 135%). Crude oil output decreased mostly in Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Iran, and Iraq, while production increased in Libya, Congo and Nigeria. Venezuela tells OPEC production fell by 472k BPD to 960k BPD, a new long-term low, amid US sanctions and blackouts. Total world oil demand growth in 2018 is estimated at 1.41mln bpd, down 20k bpd from last month’s estimate due to weaker Q4 2018 oil demand data from OECD Asia-Pac. For 2019, oil demand growth is forecast at around 1.21mln bpd vs last month’s 1.24mln bpd forecast due to slower-than-expected economic activity, the EIA also cut its 2019 world oil demand growth. Non-OPEC oil supply growth in 2018 was revised up by 160k bpd from the previous month’s report. Non-OPEC oil supply growth in 2019 was revised lower by 60k bpd to average 2.18mln BPD.

* WTI FUTURES (K9) SETTLE USD AT USD; BRENT (M9) SETTLES USD AT USD. The oil complex marched forward on Wednesday to re-test YTD highs seen earlier in the week. The US energy inventory data is bound to have muddied the waters for participants, where crude stocks built by a hefty 7mln bbls, above the expected 2.3mln build and superseding the API reported 4.1mln build; however, gasoline stocks moved in the opposite direction, drawing by 7.7mln bbls, greater than the expected 2.3mln draw; the Cushing, Oklahoma delivery hub also reported stocks drawing by 1.1mln bbls. Price movements were choppy after the release. It's worth keeping in mind that the energy complex is underpinned by supply-side woes emanating from conflicts in Libya, markets are pricing in a potential disruption. El-Sharara oil field is currently producing under capacity (290k vs. full capacity of 300-315k), whilst an explosion occurred near a pipeline that connect El-Feel oilfield (340k) to Zawiya port (scheduled to load 6mln barrels in April). Recent ICE & CME data continues to show long positions expanding in WTI and Brent, with analysts at PVM noting, “a word of caution is in order. The current overhang of speculative length in both crude markers could spark a downward spiral in oil prices. That is if the uncertainty surrounding the global economic outlook and OPEC+ production strategy in the second half of the year intensifies. You’ve been warned.” Elsewhere, there were signs that the WTI/Brent arb is weighing on US exports, which declined to 2.35mln BPD in the week (vs 2.7mln last week).

* SPX +0.4% at 2889, NDX +0.6% at 7611, DJI 0,0% at 26160. SECTORS: Communications +1.2%, Cons Discretionary +0.5%, Cons Staples +0.3%, Energy +0.4%, Financials +0.3%, Healthcare +0.1%, Industrials 0.0%, Materials 0.0%, Tech +0.7%, Telecoms +0.3%, Utilities -0.4%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) was a dragger on indices again today after it reported a big fall in 737 MAX orders in March as well as receiving a price target lowering at JPMorgan. Levi Strauss (LEVI) surged on its debut public earnings release, where it showed strong advances in top and bottom line growth. Conagra Brands (CAG) outperformed following an investor presentation where it provided optimistic guidance. Delta Air Lines (DAL) opened higher on strong earnings and improved revenue guidance. AmerisourceBergen (ABC) nosedived after Evercore downgraded the drug distributor on profit concerns. Disney (DIS) received a tailwind from BMO Capital upgrading and raising the price target for the stock. Chipmakers (AMD, XLNX, INTC) caught a bid amidst a bullish research note on the sector from Cowen, who sees the sector recovering in H2 2019. Automakers, particularly Tesla (TSLA) and General Motors (GM), gained upward momentum following US lawmakers suggesting a bill for increased tax credits for electric vehicles. Kroger (KR) benefitted from a positive mention at Credit Suisse, who see robust profit ahead. Nordstrom (JWN) traded higher after KeyBanc upgraded the apparel retailer. Jet Blue Airways (JBLU) took off on improved March traffic and the teasing of a new transatlantic route. Under Armour (UAA) opened in the green with thanks to an upgrade at Citi.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLE 5 TICKS HIGHER AT 123-25+. Decent IP data out of Europe helped the TPLEX find sellers in the premarket, though buyers emerged ahead of the US cash equity open. A mixed CPI report (headline up, core down) saw a chunky block in the TY June contract. After the data, ECB President Draghi’s reiteration of downside risks saw the T-note move in sympathy with the Bund, sending Treasuries to 1-week highs. There was a breather after the European cash close, where book squaring was reported ahead of the 10-year auction. The auction itself was fairly good, stopping through the screens by 1bps, while indirect bidder participation provided some encouragement. The Fed’s latest meeting minutes stuck to the script, though perhaps weren’t as dovish as some might have predicted after the outcome of the March policy meeting. That left major curve spreads mixed at settlement.

* 30-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: The February auction saw the lowest yield at a 30s auction since July 2018, though cover slipped versus the previous month. Analysts at SocGen note that current 30s are trading fair in asset swap from a relative value perspective, but the 5s30s has flattened form multi-month highs at the end of March. The bank also says that the WI is trading beneath all of the 30-year auction stop-out rates since January 2018, which could be a negative factor leading to poor takedown. However, it does say that the current 30 trades rich in repo, which could offset negative factors, and accordingly, it holds a slight negative bias going into the auction.

* FX WRAP: As we head into APAC trade, there is a feeling of disappointment that FX moves were so limited on what had been dubbed “Super Wednesday”. The EUR trades up 0.1%, rebounding from losses seen through the ECB press conference as Draghi reiterated downside risks (there wasn’t much new). The DXY is down around 0.1% after the Fed continued to signal a ‘wait and see’ approach. The AUD was higher on short-covering, with the RBA’s Debelle overnight not signalling any easing bias from the central bank. GBP bias was to the upside amid a slightly stronger EUR and weaker GBP; sterling is seen as a buy on dips, as traders price out the no deal downside, and with an extension likely to be be signed-off on by the end of this week, no deal Brexit concerns will be booted into the long grass for another day. EMFX was up, particularly the BRL which gained on the central bank governor making pro business noises, while the economy minister reiterated his drive for pension reform. The ZAR was an outperformer, with wires attributing the strength to an easing of US/China tensions.

FOMC Minutes: Majority of policy makers expected rates to remain steady this year; majority said Fed's patient approach on rates is needed given uncertainties including global and financial developments
content:
Rate Path

  • Some policymakers thought a modest hike could be warranted later this year
  • Several policymakers said their view could change on the Fed's next move, whether that should be a hike or a cut
  • Several said Fed's characterisation as patient needs to be reviewed regularly
  • A couple said the Fed's patient approach should not be seen as limiting the Fed's playbook

Balance Sheet & Reserves

  • Several policymakers preferred to stabalise reserves by resuming treasury purchases soon after balance sheet runoff
  • Some policymakers said they should discuss cost benefits of tools to reduce reserves demand and support interest rate control

Outlook

  • Policymakers saw continued US economic growth, strong labour market and inflation near the Fed's objective as the most likely outcome in the next few years
  • A few policymakers said that uncertainty remained elevated over Brexit and trade although the likelihood of tail risk outcomes had fallen
  • Several policy makers expressed concern over the flat yield curve, but highlighted that the historical relationship is less reliable
analysis_details: Net/net, the minutes reiterate the view that the Fed is firmly on hold, and that if data comes in in line with expectations, the next move could be up. This may have disappointed the doves, who were looking to the meeting minutes for evidence that the Fed was/may consider cutting rates in the months ahead, as US President Donald Trump and his Fed Board nominee Stephen Moore have called for. The probability of a rate cut was relatively unchanged in wake of the minutes, according to money markets, which imply a 55% chance of a rate cut; some have argued that there is little in the economic landscape that makes a compelling case for rate cuts at present, and as such the pricing could be a reflection of the market’s view that we are at/near the end of the cycle; it could also be a function of threats to the Fed’s independence from the Trump administration, which prefers lower rates. Either way, there is not much in the minutes that significantly shifts the Fed’s narrative, and as such, it will be in wait and see mode in the weeks/potentially months ahead.

content:
* WEEK'S SUPPLY: The US Treasury will this week auction USD 78bln in 3-year (USD 38bln, Tue), 10-year (USD 24bln, Wed) and  30-year (USD 16blnm Thu). With USD 77.8bln maturing at month-end settlement, the auctions will raise around USD 200mln in new  cash, according to TD Securities. The bank adds that with USD 180mln maturing on the Fed's balance sheet, there will be nearly no  add-ons at mid-month settlement.  

* 10-YEAR PREVIEW: The last 10s auction stopped-through the screens, and saw the lowest yield at auction since Jan 2018; cover,  meanwhile, was the highest since June, with dealers taking their lowest takedown since March 2017, leaving investment funds with  a slightly higher takedown, while foreign participation was relatively unchanged. The latest positioning data indicated dealer holdings  rose to a 5-week high in the latest data, to USD 13.89bln. Analysts at SocGen said that the sector appears cheap for the current  auction cycle on asset swap vs the March auction cycle, and also says that the current 10 is cheap on the curve vs 5s and 30s.  SocGen thinks the auction is likely to see a positive takedown.

Brazilian Central Bank Chief Neto says the bank's mission is to achieve the inflation target, not growth; says we wont take risks keeping inflation under control
Daily FX Wrap: super Mario drags Euro down on super Wednesday
content:
EUR

Not the biggest G10 loser or mover, but certainly heading into the EU Brexit Summit and FOMC minutes on a weaker footing across the board after a dovish post-ECB policy meeting press conference and Q&A. To recap, headline inflation could slow further in coming months before bottoming in September, and while core measures are muted they are also expected to pick up and continue to converge with the Bank’s price target. However, risks to the economic outlook remain to the downside and the GC recognises the growth slowdown. Hence, TLTRO3 terms are still being assessed, with details to come in following months (June before the 1st targeted repo in September?) and the principle purpose of the April meet was to reassert a readiness to act if required. To that end, there was unanimity about using all instruments, albeit no discussion yet about deployment, including QE and a tiered deposit system. Eur/Usd is hovering just above a new 1.1230 EU session low having topped out ahead of 1.1300 again and retesting, but not breaking through DMA and Fib convergence between 1.1280-84.

USD/GBP

Both beneficiaries of the single currency’s demise to an extent, as the DXY rebounded from 96.860 lows to a fresh 97.223 peak for the day so far, awaiting FOMC minutes, and after little net reaction to mixed US CPI data that formed another part of the headline acts making up ‘super Wednesday’. Meanwhile, Eur/Gbp retreated to and briefly below 0.8600 and Cable peered above 1.3100 at one stage after German Chancellor Merkel made supportive comments about a further A 50 extension and possible a relatively short one more in line with what the UK wants (June 30). However, the reality and EU consensus appears to be 9 or 12 months with a get-out clause if a withdrawal deal can be reached – all eyes now on the emergency Brexit Summit that is die to start at 16.00GMT.

NOK

Out on its own at the front of the major pack after sharing the lead with the AUD earlier, as firmer than forecast Norwegian CPI data adds more justification for the Norges Bank to continue its normalisation cycle in the 2nd half of 2019, as signalled. Eur/Nok has extended its decline in response through near term chart support to 9.5770 vs Aud/Usd easing back from 0.7150+ again, though still underpinned in wake of more neutral compared to dovish rhetoric from RBA deputy Governor Debelle.

CHF

The Franc has weakened vs the Dollar and Euro even though the single currency was undermined by ECB President Draghi’s comments as noted above. Indeed, Usd/Chf broke out of a tight range around par to 1.0030 and Eur/Chf is close to the upper end of a 1.1284-55 range, with the inclination to suggest official intervention even though there is no hard evidence.

JPY/NZD/CAD

The Yen is inching back towards Tuesday’s highs vs the Greenback, but has not breached 111.00 as yet to take another look at 100 DMA resistance or support for the headline pair at 110.90. However, a close below the 21 DMA (111.07) would be technically bearish and the Fed could provide more impetus depending on how dovish or hawkish the aforementioned minutes are perceived to be. The Kiwi has slipped alongside the Aussie to sub-0.6750 against its US counterpart as the Aud/Nzd cross inches close to 1.0600 and the Loonie is pivoting 1.3350 within a firmer/wider 1.3362-18 band.

DJIA

Elsewhere, WSJ reports that the co. did not receive any commercial orders for its 737 MAX jets in March and delivered just 11, under half the normal rate. (Newswires/WSJ)
  • Caterpillar (CAT) – Morgan Stanley has raised its PT on the industrials co. to USD 165 from USD 160, where analyst Courtney Yakavonis maintains her Overweight rating, citing that although some of its portfolio is “clearly approaching peak”, she expects its mining segment to offset losses in construction. (Newswires)
  • Cisco (CSCO) - The communications equipment company has named Jacqueline Guichelaar as the new CIO, according to a company spokesperson. (Newswires)
  • Exxon Mobil (XOM) – The energy giant expects Q1 2019 corporate and financing expenses to be between USD 700mln-900mln. Sees Q1 upstream volumes consistent with Q4 2018; sees Q1 downstream industry refining margins lower. (Newswires)
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) – The health care conglomerate reportedly targeted its baby powder products at less health-savvy minorities, where an internal marketing presentation from 2006 said "under developed geographical areas with hot weather, and higher AA population," where AA refers to African-Americans. (Newswires)
  • Merck (MRK) – The pharma co., alongside AstraZeneca (AZN), have received European Commission approval for their breast cancer treatment, Lynparza. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • L3 Technologies (LLL) – The defence technology firm has been awarded an Australian Airforce Contract worth over USD 1bln and will deliver four state of the art aircraft. (Newswires)
  • Lockheed Martin (LMT), Intel Corp (INTC) - Mercury Systems (MRCY) has announced that it will offer an Intel solution with Lockheed Martin. The solution that will be manufactured and tested in Mercury’s facilities and is expected to be delivered to the market by mid-2019. (Newswires)
  • Michael Coors Brewing (TAP) – The brewer has announced that two of its biggest brands will be available to consumers in Singapore through Amazon’s (AMZN) two-hour online delivery service. (Newswires)

 

NASDAQ

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – Alphabet’s startup Wing has secured approval for the world’s first drone delivery service, where it is first set to launch in Australia. Elsewhere, YouTube is developing chose-your-own-adventure-style shows in efforts to grow viewers and sales. (Newswires)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – The retailer’s Whole Foods Market unit has now expanded its fresh produce delivery service to more locations in the US, where the service is now available in 75 US metros, with more expansion to come. Elsewhere, a co. executive has told staff that Go stores are to start accepting cash, according to CNBC. (Newswires/CNBC)
  • Ctrip.Com (CTRP) – The Chinese holidays co. is looking to raise USD 800mln in a convertible bond sale, which could launch as soon as this month. (Newswires)
  • Gilead Sciences (GILD) – The pharma co. has been upgraded to Buy from Neutral at UBS and its PT raised to USD 77 from USD 75, where analyst Carter Gould cites the co.’s announcement of "two important clinical wins" in the positive Descovy PrEP data and filgotinib Finch1/3 data as a potential unlocking of two USD 2bln-plus revenue streams. (Newswires)
  • JD.com (JD) – The Chinese retailer is looking to layoff 8% of its workforce, which is more than 12,000 jobs, according to The Information. However, The China Global Times reported that the co. denied the claims of headcount reduction. (The Information/Global Times)
  • Wynn Resorts (WYNN) – Following the Nevada Gaming Control Board’s probe into the casinos/resorts co.’s handling of sexual misconduct allegations, in particular against its founder, the board has determined that current CEO Matt Maddox is “suitable” to run the co. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Bed Bath & Bed (BBBY) – The co. has been called upon by an investor group to be more transparent in the delivery of their Q4 results, saying that the domestic merchandise chain has long exhibited substandard disclosures that are below the level of their public peers. (Newswires)
  • Jet Blue (JBLU) – Rumours have intensified that the airline will announce a transatlantic route on April 10th at an ‘all hands’ meeting at JFK airport. The airline also reported March traffic +7.9%; capacity +12.6%; load factor at 85.3%, down by 3.7 points from March 2018. Narrows Q1 RASM view to down by c. 3.1% from down 1.5%-3.5%. (Newswires)
  • Lyft (LYFT) - Uber is expected to make an IPO registration where USD 10bln of common stock will be offered at a valuation of between USD 90-100bln; the co. also said that the valuation was affected by the performance of Lyft (LYFT). (Newswires)
  • PG&E (PCG) - A US bankruptcy judge has deferred a ruling on whether to allow PG&E to pay its 10,000 employees USD 350mln in bonuses, saying he wants more information from the company and that the plan ‘doesn’t feel quite right yet’. (Newswires)

content:
• Compliance of members bound by supply cut deal reported at 155% (exp. 135%)
  • Crude oil output decreased mostly in Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Iran, and Iraq, while production increased in Libya, Congo and Nigeria.
  • Venezuela tells OPEC production fell by 472k BPD to 960k BPD, a new long-term low, amid US sanctions and blackouts
  • Total world oil demand growth in 2018 is estimated at 1.41mln bpd, down 20k bpd from last month’s estimate due to weaker Q4 2018 oil demand data from OECD Asia-Pac
  • For 2019, oil demand growth is forecast at around 1.21mln bpd vs last month’s 1.24mln bpd forecast due to slower-than-expected economic activity
  • Non-OPEC oil supply growth in 2018 was revised up by 160k bpd from the previous month’s report, mainly due to upward revisions in UK, Brazil and China, and is now estimated to at 2.90mln BPD to average 62.37mln bps.
  • Non-OPEC oil supply growth in 2019 was revised lower by 60k bpd to average 2.18mln BPD, due to prolonged maintenance in Brazil, Canada, and Kazakhstan which offset some upward revisions to US and Russia

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 10th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European indices have been grinding higher [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.5%], diverging from the downbeat performance seen overnight
  • Relatively quiet on the Brexit front ahead of today’s emergency summit [11:00CDT/17:00BST], recent reports highlight that MP’s are considering motions for PM May’s resignation
  • In FX markets, the AUZ & NOK outperform on inflation data and less dovish RBA comments, as the DXY pivots the 97.0 level ahead of today’s risk events
  • Looking ahead, highlights include  US CPI, ECB Rate Decision, FOMC Minutes, Special EU Council meeting on Brexit, OPEC Monthly Report, ECB's Draghi; BoE's Ramsden & Fed's Quarles

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly negative amid spill-over selling from Wall St where all majors finished lower and the S&P 500 snapped an 8-day win streak as sentiment was pressured by EU-US trade tensions and downward revisions to IMF's global growth forecasts. ASX 200 (U/C) was initially subdued with the energy sector pressured by a pullback in oil prices and with heavy losses seen in Crown Resorts after Wynn Resorts abruptly ended takeover talks, although the index has since pared its losses amid strength in gold miners, tech and the largest weighted financials sector. Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) suffered from the recent flows into JPY and disappointing Machine Orders, while Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (U/C) conformed to the global downbeat risk tone amid further PBoC inaction and as participants awaited upcoming central bank activity and any fresh developments in the US-China trade saga. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher as they tracked gains in T-notes amid the risk averse tone across the region, while the BoJ were also present in the market with today’s Rinban operation heavily focused on the belly.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7110 (Prev. 6.7142)

US

Fed's Clarida (Voter, Neutral) said the jobless rate may have room to decline without inflation and that it makes sense for the Fed to remain open minded amid a constantly evolving economy. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Hammond suggested MPs could revoke Article 50 to prevent a no-deal sinking value of GBP. (Guardian/Telegraph)

UK Brexit Minister Barclay stated that he does not want a delay to Brexit of up to a year, adding that they key to a delay would be being able to terminate the extension early. (Newswires)

Grassroot Tory party groups are said to consider motions calling for replacement of UK PM May with MPs said to want a new leader by late July. (Telegraph) Subsequently, ITV's Paul Brand tweets "1922 Committee’s executive meeting today. Understand they will discuss UK’s exit and also PM’s. They are floating timetable of resignation 22nd May-ish, with hustings and leadership contest over summer.". (Twitter)

UK GDP Estimate MM (Feb) 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.0% (Prev. 0.5%)

- UK GDP Estimate YY (Feb) 2.0% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.4%)

- UK GDP Est 3M/3M (Feb) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.2%)

Norwegian Consumer Price Index YY Mar 2.9% vs. Exp. 2.8% (Prev. 3.0%)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea Leader Kim called current situation tense and urged officials to pursue party strategy of economic development with a sense of self-reliance, during the country’s politburo meeting. (KCNA) Saudi-led coalition conducted strikes on Houthi target in Yemen's capital. (Newswires)

Exit polls and initial results show that Benjamin Netanyahu is on course to take victory in the Israeli elections and build his fifth coalition government. (Newswires)

Turkish Finance Minister Albayrak says that they will only announce 2019 measures in their economic plan today; adds now is the time for reforms; Plan to give government debt security worth TRY 28bln to public banks.

EQUITIES

Major European indices have been drifting higher [Eurostoxx 50 +0.5%] since the open following on from a downbeat Asia-Pac session where equity markets conformed to the negativity seen on Wall Street.  European bourses are mostly higher by around 0.2-0.3% whilst the FTSE 100 (Unch) remains the laggard ahead of the crucial Brexit summit set to take place later today. Broad-based gains are seen across most sectors, although some underperformance is experienced in healthcare names.  JP Morgan (from today’s note) believe that the consumer sector is currently the most oversold sector in Europe whilst autos “may be seeing tentative signs of recovery”. Furthermore, analysts at JPM think that the banking sector continues to look cheap and “continued underperformance means valuations remain extreme historically, notably on dividend yields where the sector now offers a 2% yield pick-up versus the market”. In terms of notable movers, UK’s Indivior (-72%) wiped out around three-quarters of its market cap (so far) after the US DoJ said the Co. has been charged with having engaged with fraudulent marketing schemes designed to increased opioid-based drug prescriptions. Finally, Tesco (+0.6%) shares rose after the supermarket raised its dividend, despite reporting below-forecast sales figures.

FX

NOK/AUD - The major outperformers and outliers, as Norwegian inflation slowed less than expected in March to underpin H2 Norges Bank rate hike guidance after yesterday’s disappointing GDP data raised a few doubts. Meanwhile, RBA deputy Governor Debelle was less dovish than anticipated earlier, with little sign of leaning towards an ease even though he acknowledged conflicting economic trends via strength in jobs vs weakness in consumption and production. Eur/Nok is testing technical support around 9.5900 and Aud/Usd is back up near 0.7150 after retreating to circa 0.7110 at one stage overnight. Note, however, hefty option expiry interest may hamper the Aussie given 1.5 bn sitting between 0.7145-25 and 1 bn from 0.7100 to 0.7090.

NZD/GBP - The next best of the G10 bunch, as the Kiwi continues to largely track its Antipodean peer on cross consolidation within a 1.0595-43 range and while Aud/Nzd remains capped ahead of 1.0600. Nzd/Usd is back above 0.6750 ahead of US CPI data and the FOMC minutes that together with the ECB meeting and EU Brexit Summit form the key elements of ‘super Wednesday’. On that note, the Pound is underpinned towards the top end of 1.3085-45 trading parameters vs the Greenback after above consensus UK data in the form of GDP, ip, manufacturing and construction output, but will be prone to what evolves from the aforementioned EU gathering and especially the decision whether to grant Britain more breathing space, how much longer and on what terms etc.

EUR - Also firmer vs the Dollar as the DXY continues to pivot 97.000, but like the index extremely rangebound just shy of Tuesday’s high and above 1.1250. Eur/Usd is still facing pre-1.1300 big figure resistance as 21 and 31 DMAs lie at 1.1280 and 1.1284 respectively, while expiries are also keeping the headline pair relatively contained (1.3 bn at 1.1245-50 and 2 bn at 1.1260-75). As noted, the ECB meeting looms and a full preview is available via the headline feed and Research Suite section.

CAD/JPY/CHF - All narrowly mixed vs the Usd as the Loonie flits between 1.3320-41 and Yen trades just below 111.00 after a fractional/fleeting breach yesterday fell short of the 100 DMA (110.90). Weak Japanese machine orders and more dovish BoJ commentary courtesy of Governor Kuroda also in the mix along with decent expiry interest just under 111.00 at 110.90-75 (1.7 bn). Meanwhile, the Franc is back on the parity handle awaiting the impending major events.

EM - The Rand has appreciated further against the Buck and is now testing 13.9700 having cleared the psychological 14.0000 mark, but the Lira continues to struggle amidst the post-regional election results tussle with little support from the eagerly-awaited Turkish Economic plan. Indeed, Usd/Try is still elevated, albeit closer to the base of a 5.7200-6700 band.

RBA Deputy Governor Debelle said he sees tension between strength in jobs and weakness in output data, while he suggested how tension resolves in approaching months will be important for future path of rates. Debelle also commented that labour market and leading indicators of employment are solid, and although he noted that consumption growth in H2 last year was considerably slower than anticipated, he added that other parts of the economy evolved as expected. Furthermore, he added they can theoretically lower policy rate if needed and does not expect a need to introduce QE, while he still sees decent growth in the economy. (Newswires)

Turkish President Erdogan said Istanbul election irregularities may result to a cancellation. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Notwithstanding the downturn from highs induced by data, in part if not the main, today’s main events lie ahead, but Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries are all holding near their lows (165.41, 128.01 and 123-185 for the respective 10 year debt futures) and erring on the side of caution in the run up. To recap, the ECB policy decisions are not seen as a game-changer or potential market mover, but the post-meeting press conference could prompt further price action and US CPI will feed into the next Fed convene and conference on inflation targeting even if the FOMC minutes are considered somewhat stale. However, the EU emergency summit on Brexit may be the headline-grabber if no further extension is approved as widely anticipated.

COMMODITIES

WTI (+0.7%) and Brent (+0.6%) prices continue climbing despite the wider-than-forecast build in API crude inventories last night (+4.09mln vs. Exp. +2.3mln) where prices saw marginal short-lived downside in the immediate aftermath. Supply woes continue to provide a short-term bullish outlook for the complex with sources stating that Libyan air force undertook airstrikes on military targets for Haftar in the City of Gharyan, in close proximity of the pipeline connecting the El-Feel (340k bpd) oil field to the Zawiya port. Elsewhere, the UAE Energy Minister emerged on the wires, stating that there is a high probability of achieving market balance by the end of this year. It is worth keeping in mind that Russian Energy Minister Novak previously stated that Russia will not extend cuts if the market is expected to be balance in H2 2019. Finally, energy traders will be keeping an eye on the OPEC monthly report which is due to be release at 12:10 BST ahead of the weekly DoE inventory and production data at 15:30 BST.

Gold (+0.1%) is essentially flat and trading within a narrow range just above the key USD 1300/oz level, as the yellow metal continues to trade cautiously ahead of today’s ECB decision, FOMC minutes & emergency Brexit summit, whilst copper similarly trades with no firm direction ahead of these key risk events. Separately, sources report that Venezuela removed eight tonnes of gold from its central bank’s vaults, expectations are that Venezuela are to sell the metal in order to generate funds in response to US sanctions.

US President Trump plans to issue 2 executive orders on Wednesday which aims to ease domestic natural gas transport and avoid lengthy disputes related to cross-border energy projects as seen in the Keystone XL pipeline. (Axios)

Libya's El Sharara oilfield is currently production 290k BPD (normal production 300-315k BPD), according to a field engineer. (Newswires)

Libya air force has undertaken airstrikes on military targets for Haftar in the City of Gharyan, according to sources. For reference, there is a pipeline in close proximity to the city. (Newswires)

Shell (RDSA LN) - unions at the Pernis refinery may expand their strike action from Saturday. For reference, this refinery has a capacity of around 400k BPD. (Newswires)

UAE Energy Minister Al Mazroui states that if necessary the UAE can increase production to 3.5mln BPD

- adds that there is a high probability of achieving market balance by the end of 2019

- He does not see any reason for Russia to not continue with the OPEC+ deal; and Russia will not raise production unless it is in coordination with the other OPEC countries

- States that Russia's & Iraq's commitment was higher in March

content:

EQUITIES

Major European indices have been drifting higher [Eurostoxx 50 +0.4%] since the open following on from a downbeat Asia-Pac session where equity markets conformed to the negativity seen on Wall Street.  European bourses are mostly higher by around 0.3-0.4% whilst the FTSE 100 (+0.1) remains the laggard ahead of the crucial Brexit summit set to take place later today. Broad-based gains are seen across most sectors, although some underperformance is experienced in healthcare names.  JP Morgan (from today’s note) believe that the consumer sector is currently the most oversold sector in Europe whilst autos “may be seeing tentative signs of recovery”. Furthermore, analysts at JPM think that the banking sector continues to look cheap and “continued underperformance means valuations remain extreme historically, notably on dividend yields where the sector now offers a 2% yield pick-up versus the market”. In terms of notable movers, UK’s Indivior (-78%) wiped out over three-quarters of its market cap (so far) after the US DoJ said the Co. has been charged with having engaged with fraudulent marketing schemes designed to increased opioid-based drug prescriptions. Finally, Tesco (+2.2%) shares rose after the supermarket raised its dividend, despite reporting below-forecast sales figures.

FX

NOK/AUD - The major outperformers and outliers, as Norwegian inflation slowed less than expected in March to underpin H2 Norges Bank rate hike guidance after yesterday’s disappointing GDP data raised a few doubts. Meanwhile, RBA deputy Governor Debelle was less dovish than anticipated earlier, with little sign of leaning towards an ease even though he acknowledged conflicting economic trends via strength in jobs vs weakness in consumption and production. Eur/Nok is testing technical support around 9.5900 and Aud/Usd is back up near 0.7150 after retreating to circa 0.7110 at one stage overnight. Note, however, hefty option expiry interest may hamper the Aussie given 1.5 bn sitting between 0.7145-25 and 1 bn from 0.7100 to 0.7090.

NZD/GBP - The next best of the G10 bunch, as the Kiwi continues to largely track its Antipodean peer on cross consolidation within a 1.0595-43 range and while Aud/Nzd remains capped ahead of 1.0600. Nzd/Usd is back above 0.6750 ahead of US CPI data and the FOMC minutes that together with the ECB meeting and EU Brexit Summit form the key elements of ‘super Wednesday’. On that note, the Pound is underpinned towards the top end of 1.3085-45 trading parameters vs the Greenback after above consensus UK data in the form of GDP, ip, manufacturing and construction output, but will be prone to what evolves from the aforementioned EU gathering and especially the decision whether to grant Britain more breathing space, how much longer and on what terms etc.

EUR - Also firmer vs the Dollar as the DXY continues to pivot 97.000, but like the index extremely rangebound just shy of Tuesday’s high and above 1.1250. Eur/Usd is still facing pre-1.1300 big figure resistance as 21 and 31 DMAs lie at 1.1280 and 1.1284 respectively, while expiries are also keeping the headline pair relatively contained (1.3 bn at 1.1245-50 and 2 bn at 1.1260-75). As noted, the ECB meeting looms and a full preview is available via the headline feed and Research Suite section.

CAD/JPY/CHF - All narrowly mixed vs the Usd as the Loonie flits between 1.3320-41 and Yen trades just below 111.00 after a fractional/fleeting breach yesterday fell short of the 100 DMA (110.90). Weak Japanese machine orders and more dovish BoJ commentary courtesy of Governor Kuroda also in the mix along with decent expiry interest just under 111.00 at 110.90-75 (1.7 bn). Meanwhile, the Franc is back on the parity handle awaiting the impending major events.

EM - The Rand has appreciated further against the Buck and is now testing 13.9700 having cleared the psychological 14.0000 mark, but the Lira continues to struggle amidst the post-regional election results tussle with little support from the eagerly-awaited Turkish Economic plan. Indeed, Usd/Try is still elevated, albeit closer to the base of a 5.7200-6700 band.

DEBT UPDATE: Gilts edge closer towards 128.00, and core bonds dip in sympathy
content: A clean sweep of UK GDP and industrial output data beats has overshadowed wider trade deficits in the fixed space if not FX, with the 10 year debt future down to a marginal new Liffe low at 128.02 (-9 ticks vs +11 ticks at best, and Bunds/US Treasuries following suit, while the Short Sterling strip has virtually reversed gains, bar front month Jun19 that remains 0.5 tick above par. Back to Gilts, and from a technical perspective there is little in the way of support until 127.78 (last Friday’s base) if the 128.00 level is breached, but the next major moves are likely to be on external impulses via the ECB and US inflation data that are due prior to the EU Summit and FOMC minutes.

subject: UK debt and STIR futures tentative after mildly firm start to mega midweek session
content: Gilts have recovered from an early Liffe wobble to inch back over parity having kicked off ‘super Wednesday’ at 128.17 compared to yesterday’s 128.11 close, but remain leggy and rather reluctant to venture too far ahead of multi-domestic data releases that come before the big and potentially pivotal scheduled events. Nevertheless, the 10 year UK benchmark has regrouped after retreating to 128.09 and carved out a minor new intraday peak of 128.22 more recently, while Short Sterling contracts are 0.5-1 tick ahead vs +1.5 ticks at best. Back to the aforementioned data, GDP will be in focus as a relatively new and more up to date growth metric, but in truth the ECB meeting, US CPI, FOMC minutes and last but not least the emergency EU Brexit Summit will grab the main attention.

However, BTPs and marginal debt counterparts are outperforming with the 10 year Italian benchmark close to a fresh 130.57 contract high ahead of IP data. Back to the ECB, no new action is anticipated following largely unexpected adjustments last month, but a dovish tone is expected and for a more detailed preview please refer to Ransquawk’s Research Suite.

Royal Caribbean Cruises (RCL LN) – JP Morgan expect cruise line operators to have robust demand this year and notes that Co. appears to be intact, citing strong Chinese tourism demand. (Newswires)

Standard Life Aberdeen (SLA LN) – Co’s CEO states that they had a very good Q1 and that there is no shareholder pressure to change CEO role. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Lynparza has been approved in the EU for the treatment of Germline BRCA-mutated breast cancer. (Newswires)

ASOS (ASC LN) – H1 sales GBP 1.315bln, +14%, pretax profit GBP 4.0mln, -87%. HY retail sales GBP 1.281bln vs. Prev. GBP 1.131bln. Co. state there is no change to FY19 reported sales, EBIT guidance and EBIT margin. Performance in H1 has been disappointing, are confident of improved H2 performance. (Newswires)

Tesco (TSCO LN) – Q4 LFL sales +1.7% vs. Exp. +1.8%. FY revenue GBP 63.9bln vs. Exp. GBP 64.1bln. Group operating profit +34% to GBP 2.206bln vs. Exp. GBP 2.07bln. Group sales +11.5% to GBP 56.9bln. Co. proposes final dividend of GBP 0.041 and FY final dividend 0.0577. Co. are well on track to meet target Booker synergies and are confident that FY profitability will be within the 3.5-4.0% margin range. Co. now expects to reach a dividend cover level of around two times earnings in FY 2019/20. (Newswires)

Metro (B4B GY) – Co. are said to be in talks to sell its Real business operations for around EUR 99mln to Markant. Metro however will inject EUR 300mln of fresh equity into Real ahead of the deal, so net-net Metro will pay EUR 201mln to Markant to take on Real. (Handelsblatt)

Diageo (DGE LN) – Co. have appointed Debra Crew as a non-executive director, as of April 18th. (Newswires)

Rolls Royce (RR/ LN) – Co. have agreed upon accelerated inspection regime with EASA, to allow for the confirmation of Trent 1000 Ten fleet’s health in the upcoming months. (Newswires)

UK Insurance Companies – FCA is warning industry that it will not hesitate to intervene with firms and senior management if it sees failures to have appropriate regard to value customers. (Newswires)

Capgemini (CAP FP) – Co. have entered a new IT services contract with BAE Systems (BA/ LN) Marine. (Newswires)

Asian equity markets were mostly negative amid spill-over selling from Wall St where all majors finished lower and the S&P 500 snapped an 8-day win streak as sentiment was pressured by EU-US trade tensions and downward revisions to IMF's global growth forecasts. ASX 200 (+0.1%) was initially subdued with the energy sector pressured by a pullback in oil prices and with heavy losses seen in Crown Resorts after Wynn Resorts abruptly ended takeover talks, although the index has since pared its losses amid strength in gold miners, tech and the largest weighted financials sector. Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) suffered from the recent flows into JPY and disappointing Machine Orders, while Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) conformed to the global downbeat risk tone amid further PBoC inaction and as participants awaited upcoming central bank activity and any fresh developments in the US-China trade saga.
